ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This class was a zoom seminar that met daily.
N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A great understanding of the Russian language topics covered in L3.
3rd year Russian!! You learn a lot! By the end, I felt at least comfortable in reading/writing/speaking/understanding intermediate russian
I greatly improved and expanded upon my Russian speaking, writing, and listening skills.
I really improved my Russian -- particularly my speaking and my writing.
Russian grammar, speaking, and reading

I feel this course focused consistently on Russian grammar (mostly aspect and case) when going through multiple topics including marital status, health, and direction/location. We also put a lot of effort into understanding verbs of motion.
Continuation of Russian

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very engaging, much more so than first year because now you can actually have pretty simple conversations. Too much is never expected from you and there is a lot of review from first-year Russian.
Strengths are the professor and TA. Irina and Ana are amazing people who will do their best to make sure everyone is learning
The instructors were very responsive, helpful, and understanding.

Strength: the teacher and the TA. Professor Dolgova is so committed to teaching Russian, and really wants you to improve. She's also brilliant and very, very nice. 
Weaknesses: This course is a lot of work, including long daily HW assignments. This is what you need to do if you want to learn the language, but it is a lot of work.
Great teacher and teaching assistant. Helpful and dedicated to students learning.

Strengths: decent language immersion for a L3 course; good amount of feedback (each homework and test corrected and returned); good availability (e.g office hours); good class balance of explanation/introduction, examples, and practice

Weaknesses: lack of pronunciation correction in class; poor student participation distribution (some students get more practice than others)
It was hard to be engaged with the material virtually, as it is the case with language courses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Class ran pretty smoothly on Zoom, pretty much like it would have last year except with less one on one discussion.

It went as smoothly as I think it could have, given the circumstances. Many times, I would speak up to answer a question and no one could hear me so my participation declined as a result of this, but that's not something that the instructors themselves could fix.
I think that the online seminar format worked fine. There was no real way to do it better than Professor Dolgova did it.

Succeeded: breakout rooms for partner speaking exercises; screen sharing textbook; TA/teacher taking notes in chat and uploading chat to Canvas; inclusion and organization of many materials on Canvas

Improved: oral tests should have a by-time schedule rather than just an order (e.g. Student 1 10:00-10:10, Student 2 10:10-10:20,...); having some sort of order to participation (e.g. in class, a technique would be going around the table) to ensure all students participate more equally
Less grammar and more reading/verbal activities would have been helpful.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! This class was so much fun and way better than first-year Russian. Would definitely recommend continuing on if youre on the fence.
Absolutely. If you are taking a language at Yale, Russian is one of the best taught because the instructors are amazing

I would definitely recommend this course to a student looking to improve their Russian skills, especially if they are nervous or lacking confidence in their skills, because the instructors are very reasonable, understanding, and helpful.
Yes. If you want to learn Russian, there's no better course.
Very engaging and makes learning a difficult language more enjoyable.
Yes! Essential development of tough Russian language concepts like aspect, cases, and verbs of motion.
Yes!
